history.content:
The principles of database systems are still extremely relevant in industry, and the concepts of SQL, indexes, query optimization, concurrency control, and recovery are still key things to learn. For me, personally, my internship utilized several 186 concepts (directly and indirectly) and I was far better off for having taken the course.

I would still recommend it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I'm not sure what you mean by "most companies use their own data bases" as that would imply everyone should take the course (because every company has to build their own!). This is not really the case, but even so there are a ton of companies that build databases these days including big ones (Oracle, Microsoft, Amazon), medium ones (MongoDB, CouchDB, NuoDB), and a bunch you've never heard of. While almost every software engineer will have to use databases at some point in their career (which this class is very useful for), many will still need to build them (which what you learn in this class is a prereq for).

The principles of database systems are still extremely relevant in industry, and the concepts of SQL, indexes, query optimization, concurrency control, and recovery are still key things to learn. For me, personally, my internship utilized several 186 concepts (directly and indirectly) and I was far better off for having taken the course.

I would still recommend it.

I have heard from some people that cs 186 is losing relevance as most companies use their own data bases.. 

i was just curious if people who have taken the course found it useful for internships and work.
history.subject: Usefulness cs 186
